Hi, Flash.  I have often wondered what Hep C treatment would be like combined with Type 1 diabetes.  Why?  Because I am in Hep C treatment and my teenaged daughter, brother in law and sister in law all have Type 1.  I do not have diabetes.  My first point is that if you were a patient of my own hepatologist, you would likely be encouraged to defer treatment.  This is because your biopsy sounds very good, and your genotype is not 1.  You probably have time to "watch" your Hep C until something better becomes available to cure it. Second, I have known people with Type 2 diabetes who have successfully completed treatment with no worse side effects.  Third, and this is the most important point I would like to make, you should do a complete investigation on whether your autoimmune illness would prevent you from entering treatment.  I have read many times that anyone with any autoimmune diseases, or autoimmune markers, can't do interferon because of the way it works with the immune system.  Actually, I heard about this web site from a Type 1 diabetic friend!  I really wish you luck.  How long have you had Hep C?

Hi.  I am type 2 diabetic, type 1b hep c and did 38 weeks of ribavirin with peg intron and am now on week two of pegasys and copegus.  Not being type 1 diabetic, perhaps there are others out there who can speak more directly to your "type" but I am still living to tell the tale of being on this treatment and having diabetes.  I read here once that it makes hba1c's appear lower and mine recently has been 4.5 which is sooo much better than it was - and not wanting to be too thrilled about it in case it was false, I spoke to both my hepatologist and PCP and neither knew much about what I had read here with reference to a false low reading - and said that I should just be happy about it - they also said if it was a false reading, it wouldn't be off by so much as to make it a concern.  This stuff does affect blood sugar levels so you'll want to talk to your docs about how often to test and how to adjust your eating.  I have had only one battle with a yeast infection (on my body, not internally) and I am still fighting it.  I believe it is both treatment and diabetes related.  Nobody seems to know for sure.  I am just on oral hypoglycemics so at least that's one way in which I'm not having to stab myself.  The pegasys and aranesp (low red count) stabbings are plenty.  I'd be interested in real information about treatment and its affect on diabetes, both types.  Thanks for asking the question.  Chin up.  We can handle whatever we have to.  That's been my belief, even during the times of feeling low.Helyn

I posted here about HbA1c being affected by tx. Ribavirin can cause the premature destruction of red blood cells and as a consequence give false low HbA1c. My understanding is that the HbA1c is determined by examining red blood cells to determine how much glucose is stuck to the cells. This is a crude description but I think it serves the purpose. Since a normal red blood cell lives for about 3 months, when the analysis is done it is based on the normal life of a red blood cell. If yours do not live that long because of the tx then the analysis will see little glucose stuck to the cell and extrapolate that the HbA1c is low compared to what would be seen in a normal RBC. I have hemolytic anemia from tx and so my RBCs live a significantly shorter life. So there is less time for the glucose to build up on the cell. Thus it appears that my average glucose is lower than it would appear if they were examining a normal RBC. I hope this make sense. If you are a diabetic the 4.5 HbA1c is almost certainly a false low. I think that with that HbA1c your daily glucose readings would be around 50. I doubt that's the case. As an aside I do think that some people's glucose is lowered by tx. This will not translate into an HbA1c as low as yours was I don't believe. I hope this makes sense to you. I figured this out a couple of years ago when my HbA1c was very low. At the time none of the doctors I spoke with had any idea about this but since I have read an article or two that cautions against reliance on HbA1c while on tx for the reason I have discussed. Mike

I believe the reason we are apt to lose weight is because we have little or no appetite while on tx. Tx can cause hyperglycemia as the literature states. I wouldn't think that a non diabetic would develop diabetes but one with a slight glucose intolerance may. As to hypoglycemia I don't know about that. I have wondered if tx doesn't have a lowering effect on glucose so perhaps it could. Mike

"Some of the symptoms of type 2 diabetes are the same as those for type 1 diabetes: frequent urination, excessive thirst and hunger, dramatic weight loss, irritability, weakness and fatigue, and nausea and vomiting. Some other symptoms of type 2 diabetes may include: recurring or hard-to-heal skin, gum, or bladder infections, blurred vision, tingling or numbness in hands or feet, and itchy skin. Unlike type 1 diabetes, symptoms for type 2 diabetes usually occur gradually over months or even years, and some people with type 2 diabetes have symptoms that are so mild they go unnoticed...."Here are a few good Internet addresses, sorry I couldn't make them into direct links.  If you just copy the address and then paste it into your browser.................http://www.diabetes.org/ - American Diabetes Associationhttp://www.aadenet.org/ - American Assoc. of Diabetes EducatorsI have read that treatment can cause a lot of illnesses, however my best thought about this is that if you are concerned about this issue and/or you have the symptoms mentioned above, talk to your doctor.  I'm sure they could add a glucose level to your upcoming bloodwork that would provide some insight.Best wishes,Helyn
